_exec_summary.SummaryText:
SUN PACIFIC MARICOPA PACKING HOUSE

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY





Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Sun Pacific utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant in two separate refrigeration systems at the Maricopa Packing House.  The A?A?degreeningA?A? refrigeration system is located in the southeast corner of the building and provides process cooling for the facilityA?A?s forty degreening rooms.  The A?A?cold storageA?A? refrigeration system in the northwest corner of the building provides process cooling for cold storage rooms and the loading dock area.   Since the cold storage refrigeration and degreening systems handle more than 10,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, the Maricopa Packing House has developed and implemented a process safety management (PSM) program for the refrigeration and degreening systems.  



As part of the PSM program, Sun Pacific completed process hazard analyses, developed written operating procedures, trained employees on the refrigeration systems, conducted a pre-startup safety review, and developed a mechanical integrity program for the ammonia equipment.  In addition to plant personnel monitoring the operation of the refrigeration systems on a daily basis, Sun Pacific has implemented a preventative maintenance program to ensure that the refrigeration equipment is maintained in good operating condition.  Properly maintained equipment reduces the risk of an accidental release.



Additionally, Sun Pacific emphasizes safe and environmentally sound operating practices and procedures through their employee training programs.  In addition to job specific and process specific training, operators and maintenance personnel receive training in fire prevention, fire control, accident prevention, safety, and first aid.  



While it is Sun PacificA?A?s objective to be a responsible citizen of the community in all of its business activities, the limited staff at the Maricopa Packing House precludes emergency response operations.

As such, an emergency action plan has been prepared for the Maricopa Packing House and a chain of command to respond to emergencies has been established.



Sun Pacific has developed a detailed Compliance Audit Checklist which is used to evaluate compliance with the Process Safety Management (PSM) and RMP regulations.  At least every three years, Sun Pacific audits these programs and any findings of noncompliance are documented and responded to and the deficiencies are corrected.



Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 



Sun Pacific owns and operates the Maricopa Packing House located at 31452 Old River Road (approximately one mile north of Highway 166).  The closest population center to the packing house/cold storage facility is the community of Mettler, which is approximately 10 miles east of the facility.



Sun PacificA?A?s Maricopa Packing House was constructed during 2003 and began handling fruit in November 2003.  Anhydrous ammonia is used as the refrigerant in two separate refrigeration systems that provide process cooling for the degreening rooms and the cold storage facilities.  The A?A?degreeningA?A? refrigeration system consists of three rotary screw compressors, an evaporative condenser, a high pressure receiver, a medium temperature recirculation accumulator equipped with redundant liquid ammonia pumps, and twenty degreening room evaporators.  The degreening refrigeration system is located in the southeast portion of the building.



The A?A?cold storageA?A? refrigeration system consists of a suction accumulator with a liquid transfer system, three rotary screw compressors, two evaporative condensers, a high pressure receiver, eight cold storage rooms, and the associated hallway, staging and shipping areas.  The cold storage refrigeration system is located in the northwest portion of the building with the cold storage operations occupying the west side of the facility.



During normal operation, the anhydrous ammonia is dis

tributed throughout the refrigeration systems.  However, during shutdowns or major maintenance activities, each refrigeration system can be A?A?pumped downA?A? to evacuate the ammonia from the system and store it in the high pressure receiver.  The cold storage refrigeration system contains the largest quantity of ammonia at the Maricopa Packing House.  The maximum quantity of ammonia that can be stored in the cold storage refrigeration system high pressure receiver is approximately 15,900 pounds (85% receiver capacity).  



For purposes of the offsite consequence analyses, the RMP regulations (40 CFR Part 68) define the toxic endpoint for anhydrous ammonia as 0.14 mg/l (200 ppm).  



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



A PSM program, which meets the requirements of the general accidental release prevention program, has been developed for the Maricopa Packing House to address the anhydrous ammonia system.  The PSM program includes the following chemical-specific prevention steps:



A?A? Written process safety information, including information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia, the technology of the process, and the equipment in the process has been compiled.



A?A? An initial Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed and will be updated and revalidated at least every five years.



A?A? Written operating procedures have been developed and implemented, and are reviewed at least annually.



A?A? Safe work practices, such as lockout/tagout, confined space entry, opening process equipment or piping, and control over entrance into the facility have been developed and implemented.



A?A? Each employee involved in operating the ammonia system has received initial training and refresher training at least every three years.



A?A? Written mechanical integrity procedures have been established and implemented.



A?A? A Management of Change (MOC) program has been developed and implemented to address all proposed

changes to the ammonia system.



A?A? Pre-startup safety reviews are performed when a modification is made to the ammonia system that is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.



A?A? Audits are conducted at least every three years to evaluate compliance with the CalARP regulations.



A?A? Incident investigation procedures have been established.



A?A? A written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation has been developed and implemented.



A?A? Hot work permits are issued for all hot work operations conducted on or near the ammonia system.



A?A? A Contractor Safety Policy has been developed and implemented.



To ensure that the general accidental release prevention program and the chemical-specific prevention steps are implemented, Sun Pacific has assigned overall responsibility for the RMP elements to the Maricopa Packing House General Manager.  The Maricopa Packing House General Manager has the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP elements.



Five-Year Accident History



Sun Pacific has not had any accidental releases from the Maricopa Packing House ammonia-based refrigeration systems that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years.



Emergency Response Program



Sun Pacific has established an emergency action plan and a chain of command to respond to emergencies at the Maricopa Packing House and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.  However, an emergency response program does not need to be developed for the facility since Maricopa Packing House employees will not respond to accidental releases of ammonia, the facility is included in the community emergency response plan, and appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders.

Planned Changes To Improve Safety



Through the accidental release prevention program, Sun Pacific regularly evaluates the need for any changes to improve safety.  Currently, the Maricopa Packing House does not have any changes planned for the anhydrous ammonia-based refrigeration systems to improve safety.
